thread.title: Made in Connecticut: Flavors only found in Hartford
thread.title_full: Made in Connecticut: Flavors only found in Hartford

author: Lindsay Cohn
title: Made in Connecticut: Flavors only found in Hartford
text:
Facebook Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Hartford, Conn.'s trademark tastes Fullscreen Post to Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed.
Millwright’s resides in a 17th-century mill atop a natural waterfall on the Farmington River. BSC Photo Studio, courtesy of Millwright’s Fullscreen Guests can enjoy waterfall views and elevated farm-to-table fare in the formal dining room or more casual eats in the tavern. There’s also a lofted space for private events. BSC Photo Studio, courtesy of Millwright’s Fullscreen Executive chef and owner Tyler Anderson honors the history of the building with his modern take on classic New England fare. His approach to cuisine is highly seasonal, partnering with local farmers and curating dishes based on freshness and availability. BSC Photo Studio, courtesy of Millwright’s Fullscreen Located on the 20th floor of the Hartford Steam Boiler building, ON20 (formerly the Polytechnic Club) is Hartford’s premier fine dining establishment, renowned for its sophisticated new American fare, exemplary service and elegant atmosphere. BSC Photo Studio Fullscreen The dining room offers stunning views of the Connecticut River and downtown Hartford. ON20 was recognize by OpenTable's Diner's Choice Awards as one of the 100 Best Scenic-View Restaurants in America. BSC Photo Studio Fullscreen Hartford native and executive chef Jesse Powers serves up progressive cuisine, like butter poached Maine lobster with citrus supremes, celery variations and lemongrass sabayon at ON20. BSC Photo Studio Fullscreen In 2008, CT native and former insurance professional Benjamin Braddock traded his policies and deductibles for barley and hops, working at Thomas Hooker Brewing Company in Bloomfield and Willimantic Brewing Company in Willimantic, before starting Hog River Brewing Co., with his wife Joy, in 2016. And yes, in case you were wondering, it’s named after the Hog River, which used to flow through downtown Hartford and still runs underground today. Alicia Millane Imaging Fullscreen The Hartford taproom's menu features an ever-changing selection of house-brewed beers — poured direct from tank to pint — as well as guest taps of hard ciders, wine and cold-brewed coffee, all locally produced in Connecticut. Alicia Millane Imaging Fullscreen At Hog River Brewing Co., the focus is on beer. But that doesn’t mean you won’t find some great eats, thanks to a brilliant partnership (a rotating residency of sorts) with some of CT’s best local food trucks, notably Brasato, Mercado, Chief Brody's Banh Mi and Yardbird & Co. Alicia Millane Fullscreen After working under venerated chefs at the Barcelona Restaurant Group, Roy Riedl set his sights on a food truck. Mercado, which he co-founded with his wife Heather, favors tapas with a seasonal twist. Winter Caplanson, courtesy of Connecticut Food and Farm Fullscreen The Duck Fat Potatoes are fried to order, tossed in bacon chimichurri and topped with a local sunny side up egg. Winter Caplanson, courtesy of Connecticut Food and Farm Fullscreen The Pork Empanada — six-hour braised pork tucked inside a crispy, flaky shell — is accompanied by a homemade sweet chili sauce. Winter Caplanson, courtesy of Connecticut Food and Farm Fullscreen The Simsbury 1820 House is one of the nation’s most historic sites. Today this landmark is home to a picturesque New England inn and acclaimed restaurant. Chris Prosperi Fullscreen Local dining institution Metro Bis relocated to the Simsbury 1820 House in September 2013 after 15 years in a cozy bistro space on Hopmeadow Street. Chris Prosperi Fullscreen With executive chef and co-owner Christopher Prosperi at the helm, Metro Bis delights diners with upscale American cuisine and an emphasis on local ingredients. It’s Zagat ranked as one of the top five American restaurants in the state and The New York Times declared it “worth a detour.” Chris Prosperi Fullscreen Customers flock across the river to Cavey’s Restaurant to experience two distinctive cuisines. Upstairs you’ll find Northern Italian dishes, while the downstairs dining room (open for dinner Friday and Saturday as well as for special events) serves up modern French fare. Cavey’s Restaurant Fullscreen Every morning, third-generation chef/owner Steve Cavagnaro visits the farmer’s market to select fresh produce and seafood, like native corn and Nantucket Bay scallops. Cavey’s Restaurant Fullscreen More than 11,000 bottles of French and Italian wine — each hand-selected by Cavagnaro — are housed in the climate-controlled wine vaults. Cavey’s Restaurant Fullscreen Connecticut’s oldest surviving Spanish eatery and Hartford’s second oldest “white tablecloth" restaurant, Costa del Sol has been bringing “a sunny taste of Spain” to the city’s South End since 1986. Costa del Sol Fullscreen Diners come back again and again for the traditional Galician specialties, like Paella de la Casa (mussels, clams, shrimp, chorizo and chicken cooked in saffron rice) and Pulpo a la Gallega (octopus with Spanish paprika and olive oil). Costa del Sol Fullscreen And for dessert, why not indulge in some of Maria’s Homemade Flan? Costa del Sol Fullscreen The spirit of the South is alive and well at Black Eyed Sally’s, widely regarded as the best spot for live blues music in the Hartford area. Michelle Gardella Photography Fullscreen This music venue and restaurant resides in a historic 100-year-old brick building. The interior is appointed with tin walls, original wood floors, blues memorabilia and folk art. Amy Etra Fullscreen Jazz Mondays bring together venerable local musicians and southern comfort cuisine, like jambalaya, blackened catfish and pecan pie. Amy C Etra Fullscreen Feng Asian Bistro & Lounge offers a variety of Pacific Rim dishes, specialty sushi rolls and creative cocktails in a modern setting, appointed with sleek furnishings, stone walls and industrial steel details. Feng Asian Bistro & Lounge Fullscreen This upscale Asian-fusion bistro has won CT NOW’s Best Sushi in Hartford title since 2013, in part for creative specialties like the Feng Shui Roll, a combination of tuna, salmon and yellowtail, topped with spicy Alaskan king crab, creamy avocado puree, tobiko and gold flakes. Feng Asian Bistro & Lounge Fullscreen Another signature dish is the Chilean sea bass, served with orzo, oven-dried cherry tomatoes, beech mushrooms, broccoli rabe and mango miso barbecue sauce. Feng Asian Bistro & Lounge Fullscreen Richard Rosenthal, founder of Max Restaurant Group, owns eight restaurants in the Hartford metro area. In 1996, Rosenthal, along with his partner Steve Abrams, opened Max Downtown. This upscale eatery — in the heart of the city’s business and cultural district — is within walking distance of the old Historic State Capitol as well as the new High Victorian Gothic-style statehouse, which remains in use today. Max Restaurant Group Fullscreen Known as the “crown jewel in the Max Restaurant Group,” this award-winning steakhouse offers prime cuts of meat, sustainable seafood and classic cocktails in a grand space, complete with 25-foot ceilings, bold lighting fixtures and giant wall murals. Kyle Adams Fullscreen Steak A La Max (Prime New York Strip, smothered in gorgonzola dolce, onions and tomatoes) is a Hartford-area staple. Kyle Adams Fullscreen 588 Franklin Avenue has been part of the fabric of Hartford’s culinary scene for nearly 80 years. In 1938, Italian-born brothers Charlie and Anthony Carbone purchased the vacant property adjacent to their gas station and opened Southern Plantation. In the spring of 1961, Charlie, along with his sons Gaetano and Carl, transformed the family-style sub shop into an upscale Italian restaurant. Carbone's Ristorante Fullscreen Third generation owner and executive chef, Vinnie Carbone continues his family’s legacy of Old World hospitality and tableside preparation. Jane Shauck, courtesy of Carbone's Ristorante Fullscreen The fresh rigatoni with oven cured tomatoes, shrimp, house-made chicken sausage and vodka lobster sauce is a house specialty. Carbone's Ristorante Fullscreen The duo behind CT’s best barbecue? Jamie McDonald, a Kansas City native and competitive eater (known as what else but “the Bear”) and his wife, Cheryl. In 2013, the pair opened the first Bear’s Smokehouse Barbecue in Windsor, Conn. Two local outposts in East Windsor and Hartford soon followed. BSC Photo Studio, courtesy of Bear’s Smokehouse Barbecue Fullscreen This casual barbecue chain serves up wood-smoked Kansas City-style barbecue, homemade rubs and sauces, and classic comfort sides, like mac ’n’ cheese, beans and corn bread. Winter Caplanson, courtesy of Bear’s Smokehouse Barbecue Fullscreen The hickory-smoked brisket is slow-cooked for 18 hours until it’s perfectly charred on the outside and juicy on the inside. Bear’s Smokehouse Barbecue Fullscreen Another historical landmark made modern is the 1870s H.H. Richardson brownstone. Now home to City Steam Brewery, this massive multi-story building features an outdoor beer garden, pool and game room, classic brewery bar and Brew Ha Ha Comedy Club. Chelsea Kramer Fullscreen The Double Burger (mashed potatoes stuffed between two 8 oz. angus beef patties, topped with cheddar cheese, bacon, lettuce, tomato, raw onion and pickle chips, on a house-made malted barley roll) is one of the most popular menu items. And to wash it down? City Steam’s flagship Naughty Nurse Amber Ale. courtesy of City Steam Brewery Fullscreen For Yardbird & Co. co-owners Mallary Kohlmeyer and Eric Stagl, it’s all about “farm to truck deliciousness.” Yardbird & Co Fullscreen Diners line up in droves for the Yardbird Chicken Sandwich, topped with pickles, sriracha honey and kimchi, and served with a side of hand cut potato wedges and garlic aioli. Yardbird & Co Fullscreen After training at their uncle’s restaurant in Rome, brothers Sal and Dino Cialfi returned to their hometown of Hartford and opened Peppercorn's Grill. Peppercorn's Grill Fullscreen Ravioli All’Arancia — ricotta and spinach-stuffed ravioli, smothered in a tomato-butter sauce — has been a menu staple since Peppercorn's Grill first opened its doors in 1989. Peppercorn's Grill Fullscreen With its prime location near The Bushnell Center for the Performing Arts, this authentic Italian trattoria is popular among the pre-theatre crowd. Peppercorn's Grill Fullscreen For Italian street food, stop by Brasato (the truck is a regular at Hog River Brewing Co. and Hanging Hills Brewery) for braised meats, arancini, meatballs, fresh pastas and burrata. The burrata wrapped in prosciutto with heirloom tomato, basil pesto, pistachios and fig balsamic is a favorite among customers. Jess Amrich Photography Fullscreen Treat your palette to the pistachio crusted honey goat cheese, beet and fresh fig salad. Jess Amrich Photography Fullscreen The butternut ravioli is locally made by DiFiore Ravioli Shop in Hartford, and finished with a sage brown butter and crushed pecans. Jess Amrich Photograph Fullscreen Like this topic? There’s also a lofted space for private events. (Photo: BSC Photo Studio, courtesy of Millwright’s)
